thread.title: Molalla city councilor convicted of lying about degree in Voters' Pamphlet statement
thread.title_full: Molalla city councilor convicted of lying about degree in Voters' Pamphlet statement

author: Steve Mayes | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Molalla city councilor convicted of lying about degree in Voters' Pamphlet statement
text:
Molalla city councilor convicted of lying about degree in Voters' Pamphlet statement Pottle.parade.JPG Comments 
Molalla City Council President George Pottle pleaded guilty Friday to lying about his educational background in his 2014 Voters' Pamphlet statement . 
Pottle pleaded guilty in Clackamas County Circuit Court to a charge of knowingly making a false statement in violation of Oregon's election laws. 
Under occupational background, Pottle had said, "I proudly served as a Flight Engineer from 1973 to 1993 with a Master's Degree in Aerospace Engineering for the United States Air Force." 
Under educational background, Pottle listed "United State Air Force, Aerospace Engineering, Master Degree." 
In fact, Pottle doesn't have a master's degree, said Oregon Department of Justice attorney Patrick Flanagan. 
Pottle, 60, was charged with a felony but pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge as part of a plea agreement. He was sentenced to 18 months of probation, fined $1,500 and required to do 80 hours of community service. 
"You clearly made a mistake. It's forgivable. Move on," said Circuit Judge Douglas Van Dyk, who noted that Pottle had no criminal record and a history of volunteer work in Molalla. 
Pottle did not make a statement during his sentencing and declined comment outside the courtroom. 
It is unclear whether he has any college degree. 
Pottle was elected to the Molalla City Council in 2010 and was re-elected in 2014. 
"I believe integrity, honesty, education and listening to community needs are vital keys to building a firm foundation for Molalla to keep growing and moving forward," Pottle said in his 2014 Voters' Pamphlet statement. 
Criminal charges for misleading statements in the guide are uncommon, Flanagan said. 
Former West Linn Mayor Patti Galle pleaded guilty in 2010 in Clackamas County Circuit Court to knowingly making a false statement on an official election document. She admitted to lying about her education credentials when running for mayor in 2008. 
Galle received three years on probation, was fined $5,000 and ordered to perform 120 hours of community service. 
-- Steve Mayes
